0.text: Mark Pagano: I want to be the first--it's probably too late, but I'd like to be the first to welcome you to Autumn Quarter 2016

8.text: This is my second Autumn being here,

11.text: how could I be any more excited than this, my first quarter at UW Tacoma

17.text: But I have to admit after the convo and everything last week it is even more exciting

21.text: It just gets more exciting as time goes on

24.text: So thank you all for coming this morning to let me tell you about what's going on

28.text: What I plan to do is this. I will take side tracks if necessary

34.text: But I would like to update you on everything that's happened in the Chancellor's office

38.text: Since our last Town Hall, which was last May

41.text: A lot of things have gone on since then

43.text: I wanna talk specifically about some things in leadership

46.text: and organizational development that happened since that time

49.text: I wanna talk about the race and equity initiative

53.text: Because quite a bit has happened in that arena since May

56.text: An update on the law school, give you a quick enrollment snapshot

62.text: I think you might all be shocked. I am on who is out there this year

66.text: Look a little bit, a very early look at our budget development for next year

73.text: A little bit because I want you all to come to the big event in two weeks

78.text: And then we're going to talk about the Tacoma and UW launches of the campaign

84.text: And then have questions at the end

85.text: So, you ready for all of this?

92.text: Alright. Leadership development. While I know a lot of these people are in the room,

97.text: so what I’m going to ask you to do is when I announce you,

100.text: if you would stand up and remain standing,

103.text: and there’s just about ten of you.

105.text: Remain standing and at the end we’ll appreciate all of you at the same time,

109.text: and I’ll ask you if you can, to stick around for a few minutes

112.text: at the end and we still have coffee and refreshments back there and

116.text: you can meet some of these people personally if you haven’t yet.

119.text: So, I was accused of causing search fatigue last year and it did happen,

125.text: I admit. I was fatigued as well, but boy, it paid dividends for our campus.

131.text: We got too brand new deans and you all met these people I interviewed in the spring.

137.text: We got Ann Bartlett, the Dean of SIAS, started July 1st, and Howard Smith,

143.text: our new Dean of the Business School. You’re supposed to be standing up if you’re in here

146.text: [audience laughs] Mark Pagano: There you go, Howard is standing up

149.text: Also, in the School of Education our search failed

154.text: in the college of education or the education program,

157.text: but we did another abbreviated search for the interim director of the education,

162.text: and that’s Brian McAlister. Brian is in the room, there’s Brian.

166.text: Also, you recall last year and there’s Ann. She just walked in. We’ll just look at her.

173.text: So, last year we brought a team to campus to look at everything we’re doing

178.text: with respect to global and international affairs.

180.text: It was a very productive visit. They gave us a set of recommendations,

185.text: we elevated the influence of honors program on campus and with that,

190.text: Divya McMillin, Dr. McMillin was promoted to Executive Director of Global Honors.

195.text: She was director before. And then as Dr. Lavitt began to organize her office

202.text: she hired Dr. Turan Kayaogu as associate Vice-Chancellor for Research,

208.text: and Dr. Jill Purdy as Associate Vice-Chancellor for Undergraduate Education. Now

213.text: I have another slide full [audience laughs]

217.text: We were busy. And as you all know,

221.text: our previous Vice-Chancellor for Student and Enrollment Services took position in New York,

227.text: and I was able to talk a team into replacing him,

231.text: Mark Pagano: and we have Kathleen Farrell and Karl Smith serving as

235.text: Co-Associate-Vice-Chancellors in Student and Enrollment Services.

238.text: Yeah, let's just go ahead and clap for them now.

245.text: And let's go backwards and clap for all those people that stood up and sit down

253.text: Now along with that same visit, we decided to separate global honors and

260.text: global affairs, and establish a new office where we consolidated several of our

264.text: international activities on campus. In a new Office of Global Affairs

268.text: And all this successful talking, Dr. Lisa Hoffman into starting that office off

276.text: getting it all set up. Consolidating all of those services.

278.text: So she's been serving as the Interim Executive Director of the Office of Global Affairs

285.text: But that left us with the opening in Community Engagement

289.text: So who else would I ask besides Dr. Linda Ishem to start serving in the role in Community Engagement?

303.text: And this all kind of domino, so as you know Dr. Hoffman did Community Engagement

312.text: And also, spearheaded our liaison work with JBLM

321.text: liaison to the military base on behalf to the whole University of Washington.

326.text: That is not part of Linda's portfolio

328.text: Instead, we move that to Michael Wark

331.text: Mark Pagano: who is in advancement. And Michael was promoted

339.text: He was already standing up, but he's Assistant Vice-Chancellor for External Relations

342.text: And has that responsibility for the JBLM work

345.text: Along those same lines, a lot of you know Roz Johnson

349.text: Roz worked with Dr. Hoffman in Community Engagement, she also

352.text: spearheaded a lot of the work with JBLM

356.text: She has taken on an additional role as Associate Director of Veterans/Military Services

360.text: beginning in Septembers, so let's hear it for Roz

368.text: And then the last thing was

370.text: we did a search for a permanent director of VIBES many of you may have known

375.text: that Thomas was serving in an interim role. He had been with us all year

380.text: And we did the search, and Tom is the best person,

383.text: and he has that role full time now in VIBE

386.text: So, this is the slate of new people

388.text: They'll be back here afterwards, so I encourage you to go meet them if you haven't yet

402.text: We need to continue the searches for SAES

406.text: And we had a visit to campus, I'll talk about that in a minute

409.text: before we start the search, but we've recruited Patrick Pow and Andrea Coker-Anderson, our registrar

417.text: to chair of the search for the new Vice-Chancellor for SAES.

421.text: We also have to Dean searches that Dr. Lavitt will being overseeing

426.text: That's the founding Dean to the Institute of Technology

429.text: And Ali, Dr. Ali Modarres and Martine De Cock are co-chairing that search

435.text: and then the search for the Founding Dean, School of Education is

441.text: So, those are all going to be going on this fall

443.text: And then in some time either in the winter or spring,

445.text: we will have to decide what we're going to do in Global Affairs

449.text: because Dr. Hoffman let me know when she first started that she is taking sabbatical.

453.text: And she is still going to take sabbatical next year, so we will have to fill that position sometime

460.text: Okay, let's go back to the SAES search for a minute

464.text: One of the things that we did over the summer when Cedric announced that he was going to New York

469.text: is we brought in the organizational excellence folks from Seattle

472.text: to take a look and interview people on campus to see how we were positioned

476.text: in that organization before we search for a new leader

480.text: They brought a team of three or four people and they were here several days

483.text: they did about fifty interviews on campus and gave us a report,

487.text: and based on that report we decided to not change anything to search for

492.text: the same kind of Vice-Chancellor position that we had in the past

496.text: Mark Pagano: They told us that we had a very solid infrastructure and firm foundation in that area

502.text: for moving forward. They said the staff were very supportive,

505.text: committed to our students, committed to this campus in this mission

508.text: So, they suggested that we not change anything drastically

512.text: And we're going ahead with that suggestion and we are

515.text: tweaking the position description a little bit to make sure all the languages is supportive

520.text: of our new strategic plan, but like most

523.text: we are searching for the same kind of Vice-Chancellor that we had before

526.text: They also pointed out some issues for us to work on

530.text: One of the things they said is now that we are developing new strategic plan for our campus,

536.text: SAES needs to develop a companion plan for their organization

541.text: They also thought that they should increase their collaboration with other areas

549.text: and that was already happening with our new Vice-Chancellor, Dr. Melissa Lavitt.

553.text: So, there's a lot of collaboration going on now,

556.text: and we will expect our permanent Vice-Chancellor to do that, as well.

559.text: They did point out some physical limitations to the space we have.

565.text: I think that would be expected when you're rapidly growing,

568.text: you kind of put some things in place, and don't completely think through

572.text: how these will look when you grow to two or three times that size

575.text: So, we're going to have to kind of look at our space and see how everything is organized

579.text: Likewise, they suggest that we think about scalability

583.text: A lot of the offices and student enrollment services are one person deep

587.text: So, they thought we should maybe concentrate on some

590.text: cross-planning or cross-training in those areas.

593.text: And then there were a few units specific functions

595.text: But it was a very good report, and the co-interim leaders have that report

599.text: and we're moving forward as we do this search.

602.text: Okay, the programs to schools, you've heard me refer the Institute and Education now as "schools"

609.text: And that's true as of September 16th

611.text: They were both elevated to "school" status

614.text: Now when we got that approved, that was great

617.text: But unfortunately, they didn't approve more budget for these areas

621.text: They didn't approve name changes. We are able to call them schools in status,

625.text: but they didn't change their names

627.text: And they ask us to search for founding deans, so they didn't change the titles of the interim folks leading

633.text: But we were thrilled to have that done, and now we have four schools at UW Tacoma.

639.text: But we need to have a plan for our other three

642.text: Mark Pagano: So, as we were preparing the report for these two to ask for them to be schools,

650.text: one of the requests was we need a plan for all of UW Tacoma

654.text: So, we put together a plan for all of UW Tacoma

657.text: We said these two are ready to go, and within the next year

660.text: we would like the others to look at getting ready to go.

665.text: and they approved these two at the last minute we put Urban Studies in, as well

671.text: and unfortunately they thought that maybe it was too early.

676.text: We need to look at more growth and development at this time so

680.text: what I proposed to do is take this year, and work with the other three programs

685.text: and try to find out what our best strategy is to move those to school status as soon as possible

691.text: I mean, we can move them until we're ready

693.text: Until Seattle, and everybody is ready

697.text: But we want to work on that, we want to keep the pressure on

700.text: to elevate all those to school status

702.text: We feel that all of our programs here are equal caliber, equal quality

706.text: They are different in size, different complexity

709.text: But I feel a little bit like, we'll leave them behind, somewhat

714.text: If we don't elevate them to school status, and they deserve to be school status

718.text: So, that's where that is right now

722.text: Mark Pagano: As you recall, I wanted to show you this slide first

725.text: We had a couple caveats to the pivot when we pivoted last December from UW offering a cohort

733.text: of UW Law here to UW Tacoma Law School

736.text: Now I was willing to take that on, however, we wanted to make sure several things were in place

742.text: And those things were that it would be congruent with our strategic plan

747.text: We were right in the middle of launching the strategic planning effort, and we,

751.text: while we want a law school, we don't want that to prevent us from doing the other things we have on our plate

756.text: Likewise, we would have to have the support of the flagship campus

761.text: of the UW Law Faculty and Dean

764.text: We have that, we have great support from the President, the Dean, the Provost

768.text: Everybody supports us in this--in our endeavor

771.text: But we also need to have significant funding

774.text: We can't take a Law School out of our hide, so to speak

778.text: That would be a little difficult

779.text: It's hard to take a person out of our hide, much less a school out of our hide

783.text: So, we are seeking a support for that.

787.text: We have a request prepared, like a placeholder

791.text: And what we're up to right now, is recall that we have to do a feasibility study

797.text: There are associations won't even let us entertain this idea without a feasibility study

801.text: so we hired Dr. Marty Katz

803.text: He's from the Sturm School of Law at the University of Denver

806.text: He's been on board with us since, I think, April, yeah met April

810.text: He's been to campus several times

812.text: And Bill Kunz has been chairing the Blue Ribbon committee that's been working with Marty

817.text: to do an an evaluation to see if it's feasible here.

820.text: When he came to campus this summer, we held several focus groups.

825.text: He went and talked to the Nisqually Tribe

828.text: They had interest in helping us if we move forward

831.text: A lot of our legal community came to campus, public defenders office

835.text: Everybody who's involved in law in the South Puget Sound was on campus to talk to our consultant

842.text: And they're also conducting some market analysis with two organizations

846.text: CAMPOS and educational outreach unit at Seattle

850.text: Seattle is doing a study force too

851.text: All this will come together in the next month or so, and we'll have a set of recommendations

857.text: And then we'll have to decide what we're going to do with the information we get

860.text: So, that's the update on Law

866.text: Mark Pagano: Well, I want to start this with a picture I showed you last May

871.text: And right before, this is May 3rd, and remember my Town Hall was May 6th

876.text: So, earlier in the week from my Town Hall, I came into the office

879.text: and I found this on the sidewalk

881.text: And you know, I couldn't help but believe that our students are right

885.text: I'm assuming the students wrote this, but it may have been Tom, or somebody--I don't know who wrote this [laughs]

892.text: He's sitting in the front row, so

893.text: Anyway, it was on the sidewalk

895.text: And I feel this, as well. And I think our President feels this

900.text: And she did say it's the race and equity initiative. It's not forever

904.text: She is talking about a four year initiative to accelerate the development of our campuses

911.text: So, we do need to start having action

914.text: So, ever since this day I have kind of tilted my thinking to not just the dialougue

920.text: that the race and equity initiative has prompted us to have with each other but also, actions.

926.text: Visible concrete actions that move us towards our goals

929.text: So, lucky for us, we were already on board, off and running, getting close to the end

937.text: of when we were going to launch and approve a strategic plan.

941.text: Well if you look at the strategic plan, and I'm not going to show it to you

944.text: because it's a secret until two weeks

947.text: But it's actually on the website. Many of you have probably gone to look at it

949.text: You've talked about it at your retreats. I know that

953.text: But anyway, two of our six impact goals are really devoted specifically to these issues

961.text: So, we are going to make progress. We are already making progress

965.text: and if you look at the other four impact goals, they have race and equity

971.text: even though they're about students, our community, all those things are tied together

975.text: But specifically, these two goals are gonna generate many, many specific actions that our campus can take

983.text: To make our campus a more equitable place

987.text: And the next--That was the fourth one and this is the fifth one: Culture

991.text: And if you read that, our campus is respectful, productive, and inclusive

996.text: You can't see it, but there's a coming soon across that

1000.text: And it kind of got washed out

1002.text: So, you'll learn about those pretty soon

1004.text: So, that was good for us, but I don't think that's enough

1007.text: The students don't want to hear that our strategic plan is going to help us get better at these issues

1011.text: So, as we were deliberating, several things happened

1017.text: And you were all here, well not all of you were here, but many of you were here

1020.text: But you remember the horrible thing that happened in Orlando,

1024.text: that happened right after, you know, our Town Hall, and everybody was leaving for the summer

1030.text: Mark Pagano: And then this happened

1031.text: And then right after that, the Baton Rouge, the young black men were killed

1036.text: in Baton Rouge and Saint Paul. And then kind of as a result to that, the sniper

1041.text: shot the police officers in Dallas, just rapid fire.

1044.text: And at that point, we couldn't wait for the strategic plan. We couldn't wait for anything

1051.text: So, thankfully, Ed Mirecki and Kathleen and Karl and several people in Student Affairs

1058.text: talked to us about, let's stage something where we can go kind of vent our frustrations and talk and reflect on this

1066.text: So, we held a day of Standing Together for Justice out at the Peace Pole

1072.text: But as I was standing there

1075.text: I was there, that's me, the bald headed fella right there

1078.text: As I was standing there, I thought, we have to start now, doing something

1085.text: Our campus is working on lots of things. We have these two major impact goals

1089.text: And our strategic plan that are going to help us as a campus become more diverse

1093.text: It's going to help us as a campus become more accepting to all cultures, things like that

1098.text: But I think out students and faculty want more

1101.text: Here we have assembled a multitude of people who are committed to social justice, to equity, all those things

1110.text: That's not enough for us to work on ourselves, our own campus

1113.text: I believe our people want this campus to be a beacon for the world

1118.text: They want the campus to do something on behalf of all people

1121.text: So, that's the thing that I struggle with

1124.text: What should our campus do as a body?

1126.text: Because we need to be very deliberate about that because it is a large force

1131.text:
5,000 students strong. 300 faculty and 300 staff strong.    
It's a large force

1138.text: So, as we move that force towards doing something positive, we need to be deliberate thinking about that

1144.text: So, what we committed to that day was hosting a series of active discussions

1153.text: Mark Pagano: Okay. So--and I committed to this while I was standing there.

1158.text: I was thinking what can I say, and I said we'll start with a series of active discussions

1162.text: And the way they're designed, is to first, we have to be--

1166.text: And I've been listening to my friends enough to know that first we have to be brave

1170.text: We have to be a little bit active

1172.text: Not a little bit, we have to be a lot active

1174.text: So, the first speaker that's coming is Bree Newsome

1178.text: Next Thursday, or maybe the Thursday after that next Thursday, the 20th

1181.text: She will be our first speaker.

1183.text: If you don't know who that is, I have tried to go learn a little bit about her

1186.text: She was the young woman who climbed up the flag pole, and took down the Union Jack flag in South Carolina

1192.text: So, she will be our first speaker

1194.text: And talk about being brave, now I'm not advocating for you all to climb up flag poles

1199.text: If you do, don't say you're from University of Tacoma, you're on your own

1204.text: As a campus, we should be doing something of similar, you know

1209.text: Impact in the world around us

1212.text: So, she's going to be our first speaker

1214.text: Our last speaker, they're negoitiating with right now, I'm not liberty to tell you who until we get everything taken care of

1220.text: but the last speaker is the same caliber of person, or persons, that will be here

1227.text: So, what we're still working on are the topics in between

1231.text: What I've asked the group to talk about, to sponsor in between is utilize some of our faculty talent

1236.text: utilize some of our community talent

1238.text: Maybe even our students to put together some discussions in between,

1242.text: and the result at the end of the year will be a very well thought out strategy

1247.text: that we can take as a campus to do something larger than just right here

1253.text: We will talk about those ones in the middle

1256.text: We will talk about discourse, freedom of speech, all those kinds of things

1259.text: Because remember we're committed also to be a very civil organization that respects each other

1264.text: As well as we move forward

1267.text: So, this is kind of the busy slide, but I wanted to let you know there are other things going on

1276.text: Mark Pagano: So while these active discussions are going on

1278.text: The students haven't waited until the end, they're going to do something on October 19th

1283.text: They have an event called "Inspirational Voices"

1286.text: I don't know a lot about that event. It's kind of been quiet in the background

1290.text: But I assume it's going to be of excellent quality, and it's going to be right here on our campus on the 19th

1295.text: Other things we're doing, we've opened a Meditation Space

1300.text: one of the things our students asked for

1302.text: We have many diverse cultures on our campus, growing numbers of those cultures

1308.text: And it's an inconvenience for them to be in class,

1311.text: if they don't have a place to have their prayers or their meditation that's part of their lives

1315.text: We do have a little room up in the Y, but you've all walked up to the Y

1319.text: That's hard to do three or four times a day in between class

1324.text: So, we opened up WG 233. It's going to open today or Monday

1329.text: I don't know which day. Monday? It's going to open on Monday.

1332.text: And it'd be open all the time that the building is open

1336.text: for our students, faculty and staff to go have a spot to do that

1339.text: Likewise, we were asked to work on a bias incident reporting mechanism on this campus

1346.text: We were asked by several people, our students, by the race and equity task force put this forward

1351.text: So, we did that over the summer

1354.text: Ricardo and Sharon and Melissa and many of you in the room worked together

1359.text: and that is just about ready to launch

1362.text: I believe that it's active in the background. It hasn't been turned on yet

1365.text: But we're trying to make sure it's ready before we put that out there

1368.text: So, the campus is moving forward on concrete action to take care of that

1374.text: Also, Melissa is working very hard on evaluating, revising the faculty hiring process

1381.text: That's kind of the number one goal of our students have asked for,

1385.text: they've asked for our faculty and staff on this campus

1387.text: to more closely mirror the diversity that they bring to the table

1392.text: And Karl can tell you that the diversity of our student body

1396.text: is even increasing more as we move forward in time

1399.text: which is a great thing for us

1400.text: And then, along those same lines, our colleagues in SAES

1406.text: are hosting a series of those Standing Together events this fall

1410.text: I think our students appreciated that time to reflect, and talk, and visit, meditate on things

1418.text: So, there hosting a series of those this fall

1420.text: And then another thing, the diversity blueprint

1422.text: Many of you may have seen that document before

1425.text: It was first released in 2010 as a UW3 campus document

1430.text: It is being re-released as an updated document.

1433.text: It goes right along hand-in-hand with the President's

1440.text: It is more like, the concrete behind it, the things you can actually do

1444.text: it puts a more teeth into the expectations

1447.text: for the diversity of our hires and things like that

1450.text: So, that's going to be released sometime,

1452.text: I would assume in the next couple of weeks you'll see that

1458.text: I'll just quickly go through this

1459.text: This is very early. We already have a budget for this year, but we have to start now

1464.text: working on the budget for next year.

1466.text: So, we have some base assumptions

1471.text: I want to increase the transparency of the budget process, and get wider input

1477.text: And I worked on this last year, but it's difficult when people aren't ready for that

1483.text: So, I'm trying to get the campus more ready for that, more engaged

1485.text: and more prepared and educated about the budget process so you can input

1491.text: We have a budget 101 kick off, on I think October 24th

1496.text: We put together a campus wide budget committee, which we call the Campus Budget Committee (CBC)

1502.text: We still have our executive budget committee, which is charged with executing the budget

1507.text: but now we have a campus wide budget committee

1509.text: that's made up of our deans, our directors, our vice-chancellors,

1513.text: our students, our staff, and our faculty leadership

1517.text: All those people together, it's about 30 people strong

1520.text: We're going to march through this summer, and prepare  ourselves to give input to the budget process

1525.text: It continues to assume there's going to be no increase

1528.text: In fact, we're in a ten percent--or five percent or ten percent--some percent decrease from last year

1541.text: No, that is the basic tuition

1543.text: Graduate programs can increase--you have to ask--

1547.text: but graduate schools, or graduate programs can ask for budget increases

1550.text: But undergraduate, the legislature has actually decreased tuition

1555.text: which is kind of why we're in a little bit of hot water

1557.text: So, last year did back fill that

1561.text: We have no guarantee that they're going to back fill in the subsequent years

1564.text: So, we may be five percent short of tuition money

1567.text: We're assuming this is good news, unless you're in charge of the budget

1571.text: Assuming another four percent compensation level next year

1575.text: Our provost, Jerry, who's in charge of the budget, he is committed to keeping salaries up

1581.text: So, we have to--and the state won't give us four percent guaranteed

1586.text: This year it was four percent and the state gave us 1.8,

1589.text: so the 2.2 had to come out of our hide

1592.text: So, over time, that gets more and more difficult to do

1596.text: So, Melissa is continuing then to match the faculty searches, with where the demand is

1602.text: We don't have a lot of flexibilty to do programs anymore

1606.text: that aren't going to have students in them

1608.text: It seems logical, but anyway it's necessary

1614.text: It's not only logical, it's necessary

1615.text: We want to fund the strategic plan

1617.text: We didn't go all the way through that year's exercise, and then say we can't do the strategic plan

1622.text: So, I've committed to putting one percent of our budget towards the strategic plan initiatives

1627.text: that we're going to learn how that's going to work in two weeks

1630.text: Kathleen is going to tell us about that

1632.text: With these assumptions as a minimum

1635.text: we still need to think about 200 additional students tuition next year to keep our budget flat

1644.text: And I've asked the Vice-Chancellors to look at approximately a one percent realocation

1650.text: They'll look internally to what we do, so that we can re-deploy some of those funds towards the future

1655.text: So, that's a beginning of the budget

1657.text: A lot of water between here and the end of the bridge

1665.text: These numbers, headcount numbers, are as of the 6th

1675.text: 5,012, that's exciting, unless they're all in your class

1681.text: And you have to grade all those papers

1682.text: But we were planning, remember, the late Chancellor had planned for a 7% growth rate

1692.text: And when I interviewed here, there was concern that was maybe a little aggressive

1696.text: and maybe we needed to tilt back a little bit.

1698.text: So, we did. We tilted back to about a 4.5% growth rate
